title: American_Top_40_1975_October_18th
description:
"From the Florida Everglades to the California Redwoods, you hear the nation's biggest hits every week at this time on American Top 40. My name is Casey Kasem. The countdown rolls on now with Leon Russell at number nineteen and 'Lady Blue.'"


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Glen Campbell passes Elton John for most weeks in the top 40 for 1975. Elton kept "Philadelphia Freedom" on the chart for seventeen weeks. This is the eighteenth week for "Rhinestone Cowboy."

Casey answers the question, "During the rock era, have two versions of one song ever appeared on the chart at the same time, and both hit number one?" Casey says no, but tells about the time in 1957 when two versions of the same song hit numbers one and two.

Casey tells us whatever happened to Timi Yuro.

A listener wants to know, "What song stayed in the top ten for the most weeks?" The song that holds the record was by a vocal group whose first hit was back in 1929!

There is a group in the countdown that was able to make $850,000 per year on the road even when disputes with their recording label kept them from putting out any new records for four years.

Another listener wants to know, "Who is the top album artist who has never had a hit single?" The answer is a fellow who has had a hit television show, now in syndication, and put twelve albums on the album chart without ever making the singles chart.
